div1.p:
Thanks for your letter. I shall surely look in on you, if only for an hour, next trip east. And I promise myself the pleasure of seeing you here, either before or after that much desired opportunity to shake your hand. I did indeed see the whole of your "Chaff and a little Grain"; and that's one reason why I was so cor-
28
dially pleased with the good things you had to say of "Brunelleschi". I demur at your pronouncement of bombast. I think I know the passages you mean. But do me the honor of reading them again, in their context, and see if they do not ring true, as characteristic of an extremely sensitive and over-wrought soul, tremulous with age and defeat, and softening toward surrender in the catharsis which prepares the soul for redemption. The redemption scene follows immediately in words as exceptional for their childlike simplicity
29
and directness, as the preceding passage is elaborate and breathless. This is drama; and if inflation, or something next door to it, (inspiration, for instance,) is a part of the mood it must be a part of the expression of the mood. It may or may not be offensive in literature, according to your point of view, but it is essentially true to life. Perhaps, after all, however, I am not talking of the passages you take exception to. One other point; the awkward inversions are a part of the drama, too, — a part of Brunelleschi's style, as distinguished from my own, 𔃉 unless I am very much
30
mistaken as to mine, Brunelleschi was a thrower-back, as well as a plunger-forward, and in speaking thro his mouth the man became the style. I am sending you a couple of things in which I speak in propia persona from which you can judge whether I am right, in a measure at least, for of course a man can't wholly lose himself even in drama.

I had ordered all your books before I got your letter, and they came just after. Then I took advantage of a couple of days in bed, of a cold, and
31
read four of them with keenest relish; the fifth is now under way, as family reading aloud. i. e. The Dawn Builder I should find it quite impossible to tell you how poignantly these books have touched me and rejoiced me. Thank God the real thing can sometimes be received cordially, as the receipt you sent me shows has been the case with your work. Your genius has the rare chance to grow in the sunshine, and it is strong enough to stand it. There are many individual pieces which I like exceedingly; but the beautiful thing, the wonder
32
ful thing, is the gradual sure emergence of the great soul, in the Bundle of Myrrh, and also in the series of books as a whole. Perhaps the Bundle of Myrrh most completely took me off my feet. The current runs more quietly, doubtless because more deeply, in the later books. But you have your greatest work still before you; and I think you point the way to it in the River and I. Rich and racy as are the early lyric outbursts, you will, I feel, gain presently in range and power by so-
33
cializing your muse. Yet the Fugitive Glory appealed to me less, perhaps, on the whole, than most of the other pieces; and I liked least of all the death of Alcibiades. Why doll him up so beyond recognition? Something of his genuine cursedness to take hold of his good points by would make him so much more real. I have a personal feeling about this, for it happens, curiously enough, that I am studying him, tho only as a very minor youthful figure, "in our nest". I wish you would spin a yarn about some of your old Mizzoura heroes. There is the right sort of stuff. And people
34
are getting used to taking their stories in verse, since Moyes and Masefield et al. have can put on, — specially Masefield. You can do this latter one better if you will, and that is saying a lot. The author of Man-Song, Stranger at the Gate, River and I, and Dawn Builder, has all of the powers necessary to do justice, in immortal verse, to the Epic of the West. As for Moyes he's not in the running nowadays, and won't be till he has lived some life and tasted "the sweet forbidden wine, crushed out with bruising kisses." You know "the pathos and the joy of human dust," and you are bound to give us more and even more of it. We can't — I can't anyway, — get too much of your sort of thing.
Come and see me and my wife and five youngsters.
